title-group.article-title: Design and simulation of a steering gearbox with variable transmission ratio

article-meta.aff: Department of Product Design, Mechatronics and Environment, Transilvania University of Braşov, Romania

abstract.p: This article presents the geometric and functional characteristics of a steering gearbox with variable transmission ratio, which contains a translating wheel (circular curved rack) in gearing with an eccentric sector (segment). The solution requires no special technology because it uses conventional involute gears, being obtained/derived from a classic gearbox with constant ratio by changing the gearing characteristics. The precision of the steering system and the reversibility of the gearing are not affected by these modifications, the driver having a good/safe control of the vehicle. This gearbox can be used for the steering systems of some low-power vehicles, assuring an increased actuating torque (less effort); in this way, the assistance (hydraulic power steering or electric power steering) can be avoided. The study is focused on the following objectives: formulating the theoretical bases, establishing the geometrical parameters, and simulating the functionality of the gearbox, based on the specific requirements of the vehicles’ steering system. Important conclusions have been drawn on the influence of some specific parameters in terms of insuring good gearing conditions, such as the variation of the distances between axes and the variation of the clearance between teeth.

sec.title: The problem of variable ratio in the steering gearbox
sec.p: Gears with variable ratio have been a permanent concern and challenge, from a theoretical as well as technological point of view. The variety of studies that tackle aspects and developments of these gears is on the raise, the non-circular wheel being the subject of several interesting applications. The references pointed here give a decisive image of these developments. Danielli1 presents a method for determining the profile of the gear teeth on a variable radius wheel, which generates important increase of the contact ratio between the teeth of non-circular gears by using a constant pressure angle for any given tooth, but variable from one to next.2 Emura and Arakawa3 describes a new steering mechanism, which uses non-circular gear, having the capability of turning a small-radius carrier. In order to obtain a variable transmission ratio, according to an imposed motion law for a gear with non-circular wheels, with constant center distance, the necessary curvature of the driving wheel results in that obtained by Figliolini et al.4 Modler et al.5 considers the motion functions of the simple linkages assumed by two non-circular centroids; the method requires the computation of the centroids of non-circular gear pairs with non-circular input and output motion and their corresponding transmission function. Mundo6 presents a concept of epicyclical gear train able to generate a variable gear ratio law, the configuration consisting of three non-circular gears in a typical planetary arrangement. Summing up, these studies, as well as others, involve transmissions with unidirectional continuous movement. Gearing in the automotive, steering box is controlled in both directions for turning left and right. The specific requirements and their constructive solutions are presented in the automotive manuals/prospects, as well as in the monograph,7 the classic gearboxes providing constant transmission ratios. The gearboxes with variable transmission ratios require special modifications of gears, like the ones covered by patents.8–10 A comprehensive mathematical model of a typical hydraulic power steering (HPS) system equipped with variable ratio rack and pinion is developed in Zhang and Wang,11 observing that the dynamic behavior of the variable ratio system is significantly different from the model with constant transmission ratio; this study does not provide specifications to the geometrical parameters of the gear.

An interesting solution for the steering gearbox is the pinion–rack gear, for which a variable ratio can be obtained if the rack pitch is variable, continuously or in steps. The rack used to obtain the variable ratio in steps,12 requiring chamfering of the tooth tip, to strictly obtain a uniparous gearing (but this involves functional deficiencies), or breaking of the linear profile of the tooth, to obtain a multiparous gearing (involving an expensive technology). The “linear” rack for continuously variable ratio13 requires curvilinear tooth profile, which involves significant modifications of the kinematic chain of the manufacturing machine tool. The gear with “eccentric pinion and nonlinear rack” does not assure the continuous increase of the transmission ratio from a minimal value to any current value, there being a cyclic variation with the pinion angle.

In this article, a steering gearbox with driving rack is presented, which can perform variable transmission ratios using a circular curved rack, the driven wheel (which is a cogged sector) being eccentrically positioned. The solution, which was briefly presented in Alexandru,13 requires no special technology because it uses conventional/classical involute gears. In this article, the theory and the numerical simulation for such type of gearbox with variable ratio are presented.

It should be mentioned that the curved rack and the cogged sector have similar curvatures. In this situation, for a cylindrical gear with centers O1 0 and O2 0 (Figure 1(a)), if there is a applied translation S1 of the driving wheel on a direction which is normal to the centers’ line, the wheel center having the position O1, the line of action A0E0 will move in the new position AE. Consequently, the gearing pole will move from C0 to Cr, and the pressure angle α0 will become αw (because there is a translational motion of wheel 1, the relative revolution center Cr is disposed on the O1 0 O2 0 axis). The modification of the gearing pole position (C0→Cr) determines the change/variation of the transmission ratio it. Figure 1.
The involute gear with translational driving wheel and centric sector (a), sector with negative eccentricity (b), or sector with positive eccentricity (c).

Points A0 and E0, respectively A and E, represent the tangent points of the line of action with the base circles; the gearing pole C0/Cr will result at the intersection between these lines and O2 0 O1 0 axis (wheel 1 being translational).

The following notations have been used: rb1/rb2 is the radii of the base circles, α0/αw the pressure angles, A0E0/AE the lines of action, C0/Cr the gearing poles, vc the velocity of the pole C0/Cr (corresponding with the rack velocity), ω2 the angular speed of the sector 2, α the angle of the fictive gear with centers O1–O2 (Cr ≠ C).

The transmission ratio for the gear shown in Figure 1(a) will be given by (1)it=vcω2=r2 which becomes variable because pole C0 changes its position, becoming Cr, so that radius r2=O2 0Cr¯ is variable with displacement S1, r2 → r2(S1). Obviously, the gear shown in Figure 1(a) has an extremely small moving range and clearances between teeth, and for this reason, it is not a functional gear. For assuring the functionality of the gear, the wheel center O2 will not be the same with the revolution center Or (Figure 1(b) and (c)), meaning that wheel 2 will be eccentrically articulated, the eccentricity being e=OrO2 0¯. So, when the rack wheel 1 moves with S1, the sector 2 rotates with φ2, the center O2 0 moving in O2, and C0→Cr (the intersection of the line of action AE with the direction OrO1 0). This gear is called gear with “translational wheel—eccentric sector”, both rack wheel 1 and cylindrical wheel 2 being constructively limited as sectors of wheel.

The joint Or can be placed between center O2 0 and pole C0—diminishing in this way the rolling radius r2r 0 (Figure 1(b)), or can be placed outside the segment C0O2 0¯—increasing the rolling radius r2r 0 (Figure 1(c)), so that in the reference position, the radius r2r 0 will be (2)r2r 0=OrC0¯=r2 0∓e

It can be agreed that the sector to be appointed as with “negative eccentricity”, respectively, with “positive eccentricity”, when the initial rolling radius r2r 0 is decreased, respectively increased, relative to sector radius r2 0. Thus, the center distance a0=O1 0O2 0 will be increased (Figure 1(b)) or decreased (Figure 1(c)) relative to the articulation distance a0=OrO1 0 (2')a0=a0±e,a0=m02(z1+z2) where m0 is the module and z1,2 the number of teeth.

An application of interest is for vehicle steering, namely the steering box of type “screw–nut–sector”,14 where nut plays the role of the rack (Figure 2). This type of steering box lends itself to a hydraulic-assisted steering (for example at trucks, or tractors), but the hydraulic assistance increases the cost. In the case of some light vehicles (automobiles and small tractors), the assisted steering can be eliminated. The compensation of the actuating forces on the steering wheel, in bend, parking, and other maneuvers, can be assured by increasing the gearing ratio from the middle position (rectilinear motion) toward the extreme positions of the rack, meaning variable ratio it. Figure 2.
The steering box “screw–nut–sector”.

The constructive solution of steering gearbox with variable ratio using a translation wheel and an eccentric sector in a normal involute gear can replace (without supplementary costs) the classic gearbox variant with constant ratio shown in Figure 2. Moreover, the assistance (hydraulic—HPS, or electric power steering - EPS) for some types of light/popular vehicles can be avoided. EPS or HPS systems vary steering assist torque,15 not steering ratios, while for the steering gearbox in study (with translating wheel and eccentric sector) the gear ratio is varied as a function of steering angle.

The classic steering gearbox, shown in Figure 2, carries out a constant transmission ratio i0 in relation with the rotation angle of the steering wheel φv. For this type of steering boxes, there is a satisfactory growth of the transmission ratio by 30% from the middle position toward the ends of the nut, which can be obtained with the solutions shown in Figure 1(b) and (c). In this way, a mechanical steering box can create the effect/feeling of an assisted steering system.16

sec.title: The motion function of the gear with translating wheel—eccentric sector
sec.p:
In accordance with the intended application, the geometry of such a gear will be correlated with the construction of a steering box of type “screw–nut rack–sector” (Figure 3(a)). In this application, the steering wheel rotation is transmitted to the screw 1, which produces the right/left movement of the cogged nut 1′ in contact with the cogged sector 2. Figure 3.
Functional–geometrical scheme of the gear with “translating wheel—eccentric sector”: (a)—central reference position and (b)—current position.

The distance D between shafts represents a constructive characteristic of the steering box, and the other parameters correspond with those from Figure 1. In the current position (Figure 3(b)), the following geometric and kinematic parameters have been marked: a=O1O2¯ is the fictive center distance (of angle α=∠AO1C=∠EO2C), αw=∠AO1y=∠EO2y the current pressure angle, and α0=∠A0O1y=∠E0O2Or the reference pressure angle (same with that in the central position), r2r=OrCr¯ the centroid radius of the cogged sector, γ=∠(O1O2,O1 0O2 0) the angle between the center lines.

It is found that the kinematical–geometrical parameters depend on the current position of the wheel, meaning the translational displacement S1 of the rack wheel and the rotation angle φ2 of the sector. In these terms (Figure 3(b), corresponding to Figure 1(b)) (3)a=O1O2¯=(S1+esinϕ2)2+(a0+ecosϕ2)2,a0=a0-e=m02(z1+z2)-e (4)α=arccosrb1+rb2a,αw=α+γ,rb1,2=m02z1,2cosα0,α0=200 (5)γ=arctgS1+esinϕ2a0+ecosϕ2 (6)r2r=OrCr¯=OrO1 0¯-O1 0Cr¯=a0-(S1tgψ+(rb1-S1cosψ)1sinψ),ψ=90∘-αw

From kinematic point of view, teeth contact on the line of action means rolling without sliding on the base circles, the line AE rolling of the circle of radius rb1, and rolling up on the circle of radius rb2. The current length of line of action AE results from relation (7)AE¯=A0E0¯+AA0¯-EE0¯

Because (7')AE¯=asinα,A0E0¯=a0sinα0,AA0¯=rb1(α+γ-α0),EE0¯=rb2(α0+ϕ2-α-γ) condition (7) can be expressed by function (8), which represents the motion function (8)f(S1,ϕ2)=a0sinα0+rb1(α+γ-α0)-rb2(α0+ϕ2-α-γ)-asinα=0

The solution of equation (8) is obtained using the Excel software, starting from the initial value of the reference position S1 = 0, φ2 = 0. Considering equations (3) to (5), the solution for (8) is obtained by providing discrete values for the angle φ2 (e.g. φ2 = 10°, 20°, 30°, 40°, 50°), for each of these values being allocated an initial temporary value of the displacement S1 (e.g. S1i). Then, using the “Goal Seek” tool from Excel, the final value Sif which satisfies the function f(S1, φ2) = 0 is searched; in this way, the correlation S1/φ2 is obtained, for each value of the angle φ2. Based on the values S1/φ2 determined in this way, the rolling radius of the sector r2r (6) and the transmission ratio it (1) are then obtained.

Because the functions φ2(S1), r2r(S1), and αw(S1) are nonlinear, the motion centroids are no longer circular. The gearing process is analyzed on the base of fictive gear with centers O1-O2, with the pressure angle α and gearing pole C, which depend on S1/φ2. This fictive gear can overlap the initial reference position, O2→O2 0,O1→O1 r, obtaining in this way, the gear of centers O1 r-O2 0 (Figure 4(a)) which have the center distance “a”. Figure 4.
Overlapping of the gears with translated wheel.

The translation of the wheel 1 with Δa=a-a0 on the direction O2 0-O1 0 will determine the clearance between teeth (Figure 4(b)), the clearance on the normal axis “n–n” of the fictive gear of pressure angle α being the distance A′E′ on the line of action, given by relation (9)jn=AE¯-(AA'¯+EE'¯)=asinα-(rb1+rb2)(α+θ0),θ0=tgα0-α0.
Concerning this equation, the length EE'¯ or AA'¯ from the line of action is known, being equals with the arc from the base circle, and θ0=inv(α0) is the involute angle.

To avoid blocking, it is obvious that the gear must have very small positive values of Δa>0 and jn>0. Setting the eccentricity (e) and a good correlation of the specific parameters (rb1, rb2, e) have exactly this purpose.
This type of gear with reversible motion from any position (“come and go”) can be functional under the terms of a slow relative motion, this being the case of the vehicle steering gearboxes.
Note: The relations (3) to (9) can be generalized also for the solution shown in Figure 1(c), considering negative values for eccentricity.

sec.title: Numerical simulations for establishing the optimal parameters of the gear
sec.p: These functional requirements must be carried out in good gearing conditions, which mean: assuring the acceptable clearances jn between teeth, without negative values; keeping the difference in distance between axes “a-a0” at acceptable values, and avoiding the negative values. The maximum acceptable values depend also on the overall dimension of steering box (basically depending on the module m0, and the number of teeth z1 and z2), but also on the vehicle type or destination.

The values φ2 are important for the steering gearbox characteristic (defining the steering angles of the wheels), and for this reason, it is important to represent the charts of the functions relative to the position angle φ2 of the sector, with other words, the inverse functions S1(ϕ2),Δa(ϕ2),jn(ϕ2),αw(ϕ2),r2r(ϕ2). Each of these variations, with the considered parameters z1 and e, leads to useful conclusions.

So, Figure 5 (the function S1(ϕ2)) shows that the influence of the number of teeth (z1) of the translating wheel is small, while the eccentricity (e) has a significant influence. For φ2 = 50°, the displacement S1 is in the range S1 = 32–35 mm (for e = 15 mm), respectively, S1 = 20–22 mm (for e = 25). It can be concluded that an eccentricity e = 25 mm, although it is constructively disadvantageous, it requires smaller rotation angle of the steering wheel.

From Figure 6 (the function Δa(ϕ2)), it can be observed that the number of teeth (z1) and the eccentricity (e) have significant influence on the variation Δa. Generally, the distance Δa>0 increases with decreasing the number of teeth z1, i.e. the radius r1. For small eccentricities (e = 15 mm), the variation Δa is too high (3 … 7 mm), and for large eccentricities (e = 25 mm), the variation Δa becomes negative—the gear blocks. It can be considered that the eccentricity e = 20 mm is convenient from functional point of view (with the following values: z2 = 24 and m0 = 4 mm). Figure 6.
The variation of the center distance Δa(ϕ2).

The variation of the function jn(ϕ2), shown in Figure 7, follows the variations of the center distance Δa, leading to similar conclusions as in Figure 6. The clearance jn becomes too high for e = 15 mm/z1 = 20–25, respectively, negative for e = 25 mm, the optimal value being e = 20 mm. Figure 7.
The variation of the clearance between teeth jn(ϕ2).

Figure 8 (the function r2r(ϕ2)) offers the answer for the requirement of increased variable transmission ratio up to 30%, both the number of teeth z1 and the eccentricity having significant influence. The increase of the radius r2r should be bigger for smaller values of the number of teeth z1. Figure 8.
The variation of the sector radius r2r(ϕ2). Figure 9.
The variation of the pressure angle αw(ϕ2).

The diagrams in Figures 7 and 8 are decisive for evaluating the gearing quality (which is given by the clearance between teeth jn), and the functional characteristic (given by the rolling radius—r2r, and respectively, the transmission ratio—it).

Eliminating the above unacceptable variants (e = 25 mm and e = 15/z1 = 20), the following transmission ratio ranges are obtained (Table 1) Γ=r2max/r2r 0≅49;44.4;41.933≅1.48;1.35;1.27fore=15mm(z1=25,30,35);Γ=r2max/r2r 0≅42.9;37.75;35;33.528≅1.53;1.35; 1.25;1.20fore=20mm(z1=20,25,30,35)

Finally, it can be concluded that the pairs z1/e=30/15 and z1/e=25/20, for which Γ = 1.36 and, respectively, Γ = 1.35, are closest to the desired purpose. Considering the resulted clearances (jnmax=1.5and0.8mm), the optimal solution is z1=25 and e=20mm (or closed values).

The variations of the pressure angle αw are presented in Figure 9, which shows that the number of teeth z1 has a significant influence, the pressure angle increasing emphatically with the angle φ2 (so with the displacement S1); from practice, the angle φ2 should not exceed 40°.14

An image of the acceptable gear solution (z1=25,e=20mm,z2=24,m0=4mm), drawn in one of the extreme gearing position (end of stroke, S1=27mm,ϕ2=50∘), is shown in Figure 10. When reversing the motion’s direction, there will be a small backlash (which does not interrupt the functionality) so that the clearance between the teeth can be annulled. Figure 10.
The scheme of the gear in extreme gearing position.

Concluding, the numbers of teeth (z1 and z2) must be quite close one to another (the translating wheel and the sector are almost equal), and the eccentricity (e) must be less than half of their radius. The graphs show a fairly large variation range of all functions, so that it generates no difficulty in finding the optimal solution when applying to the steering boxes of the vehicles. The optimal correlation of the parameters (z1, z2, e) is always possible (for a certain module m0) for the sector with negative eccentricity (Figures 1(b) and 3). For the sector with positive eccentricity (Figure 1(c)), the simulations lead to inconvenient variations; this is the reason for not presenting these simulations.

In another application, the following data have been considered: m0 = 2 mm, e = 7.5, 10, 12.5 mm, keeping z2 = 24 and z1 = 20, 25, 30, 35 (similar with the previous application). From the results shown in Figure 11, similar conclusions with the previous application have been obtained, but with a larger number of acceptable solutions. It should be noted that, because the sector radius r2 is half of the value in the previous application, the displacements S1 (which are required to obtain the angles φ2) are also reduced by half (Figure 11(a)), as well as the clearances between teeth (Figure 11(b)), keeping the variation range of the transmission ratio (Figure 11(c)). Figure 11.
The geometric–kinematic functions for the gear with m0 = 2.
The application with m0 = 2 defines the constructive range of values of the steering boxes for which the gear with translating wheel has sufficient values of optimal geometric parameters.

The evolution/variation of the clearance between teeth during the gearing process is an important criterion for the transmission quality. For the selected/optimum variant (z1 = 25, e = 10/20 mm), the values of the clearance for discrete positions of angle φ2, are shown in Table 2. Table 2.

In the central gearing position, which is the frequently used working zone of the steering (vehicle running on quasi-rectilinear trajectories), the values of the clearances are very small (about 10−2 mm). In this way, the precision of the steering system as well as the reversibility of the gearing are not affected, the driver having a good/safe control of the vehicle.

Other issues regarding the transmission quality (as efficiency, noise, vibration, and harshness) do not differ from those of involute cylindrical gears, the category to which the proposed gearbox with variable ratio belongs.

sec.title: Conclusions
sec.p: The gear with translational rack and eccentric sector is characterized by a nonlinear motion function ϕ2(S1), and respectively, variable geometric-functional parameters, like the increasing variation of the rolling radius of the sector as result of moving the gearing pole Cr on the center line.

The variation of the rolling radius r2r determines the increasing variation of the transmission ratio from the middle position to the extreme positions of the rack (the functional motivation of the gear).

For this gearbox, a strict correlation of the geometric parameters (module—m0, numbers of teeth—z1/z2, and eccentricity—e) is necessary for obtaining a good gearing process (acceptable values of the clearances between teeth) and functionality (the necessary transmission ratio).
The numeric simulations reveal that the rack curvature must be large enough, turning itself into a translating wheel, from constructive point of view.

The optimal number of teeth of the translating wheel is close to the number of teeth of the sector, z1≅z2. If z1 is significant smaller than z2, exaggerated clearances between teeth will result, while if z1 is significant larger than z2, there will be no significant increases of the ratio it.
The eccentricity of the cogged sector needs to be relatively high, but without exceeding half from the sector radius (e<r2 0/2), in order to keep the clearances between teeth in acceptable limits.

The gear works properly only for positive variations of the center distance and of the clearances between teeth. These variations can be maintained in acceptable limits by the optimal correlation of the parameters z1/e (for given values of the module m0, and the number of teeth of the sector z2).
The nominated gear, which was simulated in the specific conditions for the vehicle steering gearboxes (ϕ2<50∘,Γ<1.35), corresponds to the imposed functional requirements.

The physical (hardware) prototype of the steering gearbox with translating wheel and eccentric sector is in manufacturing/refining stage in the Center of Technology, Innovation and Business from Transilvania University of Braşov. The prototype will be tested on a real steering, creating a good perspective for the research in the field. This will allow a relevant comparison between the theoretical analysis and the data achieved by measurements (in terms of steering effort, precision, and reversibility).
